question: What is the value of the glomerular filtration rate below which it is classified as an end-stage renal disease (ESRD)?
Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by loss of how much protein in urine?
Which of the following is correct about the quality of pain in the case of nephrolithiasis?

answers.option: Pain is mild and is only felt when urinating
Pain radiates to back, flank, and groin region

question: Which of the following is not kidney cystic disease?
Which of the following crystal is deposited in gout?
What is the most common abnormality of hemodialysis?
What is prerenal azotemia caused by?
Which of the following is not seen in chronic renal failure?
Which of the following cells undergo developmental disturbance in severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)?

answers.option: NK cells, B cells, and T cells

question: A 10-year-old girl complained of increasing fatigue and passing dark-colored urine for one week. She had a sore throat two weeks ago. On physical examination, there is no fever, and blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Laboratory studies show her serum creatinine is 2.8 mg/dL and urea nitrogen 24 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 2+ blood, 1+ protein, no glucose, and no ketones. Microscopic urinalysis shows dysmorphic RBCs. A renal biopsy on microscopic examination shows glomerular hypercellularity, with polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) present. Electron microscopy shows subepithelial electron-dense humps. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be present in this girl?
A 38-year-old woman came with severe suprapubic pain. Urine analysis showed neutrophils without a cast, cloudy, and foul-smelling urine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is deficient in severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)?
Which of the following is a complication of acute pyelonephritis?

A 35-year-old male presents with features of nephrotic syndrome. In addition, there is microscopic haematuria. Renal biopsy shows partial sclerosis affecting some of the glomeruli. Sclerosed areas show IgM and C3 on immunofluorescence. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 4-year-old girl presents with severe pitting edema. Further investigations show hypoalbuminemia, lipiduria, and 3.8 g proteinuria. Biopsy confirms the renal disease. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of proteinuria in this patient?

answers.option: Anti–glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies cross reacting with alveolar basement membranes

question: Which of the following clinical symptoms differentiates pyelonephritis from cystitis?
In which of the following conditions coarse, discrete corticomedullary scars overlying blunted calyces along with flattened papillae are found?

A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of cola-colored urine and reduced urine output for the past 2 days. He has a past history of being treated for a sore throat infection 3 weeks ago. His blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg. Urinalysis reveals red cell casts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the most common cause of chronic renal failure?
Which of the following causes hypernatremia?

A 43-year-old man complains of malaise for 3 weeks. On examination, his blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg, and presents with pitting edema of the lower extremities. Urinalysis shows no glucose, blood, ketones, nitrite, or urobilinogen, and the microscopic urinalysis reveals no RBC/HPF and only 1 WBC/HPF, 24-hour urine protein is 4.1 gm, serum creatinine is 3.5 mg/dL with urea nitrogen of 38 mg/dL. His hepatitis B surface antigen is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 5-year-old boy presents with generalized edema and periorbital edema. Further investigations show hypoalbuminemia, lipiduria, and 3.7 g proteinuria. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause in this patient?

A 5-year-old boy has had swelling around his eyes for one week, and he has been lethargic. On examination, he has periorbital edema. His temperature is 37°C, pulse is 75 bpm, respiratory rate is 22/minute, and blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Urine examination shows a specific gravity of 1.010 and a pH of 6.5, with 4+ protein, no glucose, no blood, no casts, and no ketones. Microscopic urinalysis exhibits fat bodies, but no leukocytes or erythrocytes. He improves with corticosteroid therapy. Which of the following is the most likely lesion in the kidney?

answers.option: Immune complex deposition in the mesangium

question: Which of the following is the most common cause of pyelonephritis?

A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency by his parents with swelling around the eyes, puffiness, and lethargy. His urine examination shows selective proteinuria with no presence of casts and blood. He improves with steroid therapy. What is the diagnosis?

A 12-year-old girl is brought to the clinic because of swelling around her eyes. On physical examination, she is afebrile and has periorbital edema. Laboratory findings show proteinuria on dipstick urinalysis, but no gross or microscopic hematuria. Microscopic examination of the urine shows numerous oval fat bodies. Serum creatinine level is 2.3 mg/dL. On electron microscopy, effacement of foot processes is seen. What is most likely the diagnosis?
What will be the effect on the size of kidneys of a person who is suffering from end-stage renal disease and has been on prolonged dialysis?

answers.option: The size of kidneys will not be affected
The size of kidneys will first increase and then decrease

question: Which of the following is incorrect for staghorn calculi?
Which of the following is the most common cause of acute renal failure?
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis causes which of the following?

A 6-year-old boy presents with generalized edema and periorbital edema. Further investigations show hypoalbuminemia, lipiduria, and 3.6 g proteinuria. Renal biopsy and electron microscopy are carried out. Which of the following electron microscopic features do you expect to find in this patient?

answers.option: Linear deposits of IgG in the glomerular basement membrane
Loss of foot processes, no deposits

question: Which of the following causes of lactic acidosis is most common?
Which condition results in thyroidization of kidneys?
What is the characteristic finding of minimal change disease (MCD)?

answers.option: Crescent-shapes seen in the Bowman space of glomeruli
Thickened glomerular membranes with "spike and dome" epithelial deposits
Thickened glomerular membranes with a "tram-track" appearance
Sclerosis of particular segments of some glomeruli
Normal basement membrane with podocyte effacement

question: Which of the following is a cause of intrinsic renal failure?
Which of the following will be a complication of chronic renal failure?
What is the normal specific gravity of urine in adults?
Which of the following is the most common radiopaque stone?
Which of the following is the most common radiolucent stone seen?

A child after a streptococcal infection presents 10 days later with hypertension, hematuria, edema, and sometimes oliguria. There appear to be elevated titers of anti-streptolysin O antibodies. What is the key morphological feature of his disease?

answers.option: Humps and deposition of IgG and C3

question: Which of the following is seen in nephritic syndrome?
What is the amount of proteinuria in minimal change disease?
In order for a patient to be connected to a dialysis machine, what must occur?
Which of the following does not increase serum creatinine levels?
In chronic renal failure, anemia develops due to which of the following?
Which of the following is true regarding acute kidney injury (AKI)?

In a 60-year-old diabetic patient, a routine lab investigation shows hemoglobin: 8.2 gm/dL, creatinine (Cr): 5.0 mg/dL, calcium (Ca): 6.7 mg/dL, phosphate(PO4): 5.2 mg/dL, with small kidneys on ultrasound. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of these is present on urinalysis in a patient with glomerulonephritis?
In pyelonephritis, what is the diagnostic urinary finding?
Which of the following is a disease that includes the proliferation of cells, infiltration of leukocytes, and deposition of immune complexes in glomerular mesangium and basement membrane?
Which of the following organisms is responsible for xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis?
How are membranous glomerulopathy and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis similar?

answers.option: Both are self-limiting and transient renal diseases
Commonly associated with the nephrotic syndrome
Occur most frequently following an infectious disease

question: Which of the following parts of the urinary tract is not a common site for stone formation?
Regarding glomerular diseases, which of the following has hump-like deposits appearing as electron microscope findings?
Kussmaul's breathing is characterized by a deep, rapid breathing pattern that is seen with diabetic ketoacidosis. What is the role of Kussmaul's breathing?

answers.option: To blow out excessive carbon dioxide to lower blood pH
To blow out excessive carbon dioxide to increase blood pH
To decrease volatile ketones from blood by exhaling them out

question: What is the reason behind polyuria seen in diabetes?

answers.option: Excess levels of sugar in urine
Increased hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's capsule

question: Regarding glomerular diseases, which of the following is most likely the pathogenesis of glomerulonephritis?

answers.option: In immune complex mediated nephritis, the autoantigen is characteristically glomerular
A causal role of T-cells in the pathogenesis has been strongly established by researchers
Complement proteins do not play an important role in the pathogenesis
TGF-β released during nephritis leads to glomerular basement membrane thickening
The pattern of antibody deposition in anti - GBM disease is radial in pattern

question: Which of the following urine findings is observed in case of an infection with group A beta-hemolytic post-streptococcal infection?
Which of the following is not present in nephrotic syndrome?
Which of the following renal calculi are larger and have a radiolucent appearance on X-ray?
Which of the following can be a chronic complication of diabetes type 1?
Nitrite in urine indicates which of the following?
Which of the following is an acquired cause of vesicoureteral reflux in adults leading to urinary tract infection?
Which of the following renal stones are radiopaque in appearance, large in size and increase the total leukocyte count?
Which of the following symptoms differentiate acute pyelonephritis from urinary tract infection?
Which of the following conditions is an example of secondary glomerulonephritis?
Which of the following is a characteristic feature of toxic acute tubular injury?

answers.option: Focal necrosis in proximal convoluted tubule
Decreased levels of blood urea nitrogen

question: Which of the following is the most common complication of catheterization?
Which of the following is responsible for the sterility of the genitourinary tract?
What is the mechanism behind glomerular basement membrane thickening?

answers.option: Uric acid build-up on the membrane

question: At which stage of the disease is glomerular capillary pressure high?
Which of the following obstruction of structure causes bilateral hydronephrosis and an enlarged bladder?
Upon examination of a patient, he is found to have a flat face and edema. His urinalysis reveals hematuria and oliguria. What is the person most likely suffering from?
What is the most common causative organism for acute pyelonephritis?
Which of the following is a tool for the classification of acute kidney injury?
Which of the following is true regarding acute kidney injury?

answers.option: Due to severe progressive scarring in kidney

question: A patient arrived at the clinic with complaints of no urine production. The attending physician ran a CT scan to identify the underlying cause. The scan showed an enlarged bladder and hydronephrosis. Which of the following could be a possible cause for this condition?
Which of the following conditions is primarily hereditary?
What do the antibodies in Goodpasture syndrome target?

answers.option: Protein in basement membranes of glomeruli

question: Which of the following is not required for catheterization?
Which of the following is responsible for xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis?
Which one of these pathologic features and disease combinations is correct?

answers.option: Chicken wire loop pattern of glomerular capillaries - IgA nephropathy
Eosinophilic infiltrate in the interstitium - hydronephrosis

question: Which one of these types of bladder diseases is correctly paired with the pathophysiology?

answers.option: Urethral injury - frequent voiding of urine
Prostatic hyperplasia - large volumes of urine

question: A 41-year-old has had recurrent urinary tract infections for 15 years. On many of these occasions, Proteus mirabilis was cultured from his urine. For the past 4 days, he has had burning pain while urinating, and urinary frequency. On examination, his temperature is 37.9°C, pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. There is marked tenderness on deep pressure over the right costovertebral angle and on deep abdominal palpation. Urinalysis shows a pH of 7.5, specific gravity 1.020, 1+ hematuria, and no protein, glucose, or ketones. Microscopic examination of the urine shows many RBCs, WBCs, and triple phosphate crystals. Which of the following renal lesions is most likely to be present?
Normal blood levels of urea and creatinine is critical for survival. What are the raised levels of urea and creatinine with clinical features known as?
Immunologic mechanisms underlie most forms of glomerular disorders. Which of the following immunologic mechanisms of glomerular injuries is most common?

A 78-year-old man is admitted to a hospital due to acute urinary tract obstruction. For the past few years, he has had concurrent bouts of cystitis. Two days before being admitted to the hospital, he could not urinate at all. What is the most probable cause of bladder outlet obstruction in this patient?

answers.option: Urothelial cell carcinoma of the bladder

question: A 35-year-old man came to the outpatient department with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. His urine D/R reports show pus cells = 12-15/High power field (HPF), red blood cells = 3-5/HPF, and triple phosphate crystals in the urine. Which of the following could be the cause of infection in such a case?

A 36-year-old married lady came to the outpatient department with a history of flank pain and difficulty in micturition. She also gave a history of weakness, fever in the evening, and a feeling of ill-health. She had not been feeling like eating recently. Her urine D/R showed 25-30 pus cells/High power field (HPF). Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate was 125 in the first hour. Her culture report was negative. What could've been the cause of her illness?

A 25-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome. The biopsy showed normal histology with effacement of foot processes on electron microscopy. Which disease is he likely to have?

A 65-year-old male presented with a complaint of dysuria. His complete urinalysis showed gram-negative rods that were non-lactose fermenting and had swarming movements. What is the most probable cause?
A female comes into the clinic with oral ulcers, hematuria, and +1 proteinuria. 1-2 white blood cells/HPF are found on urinalysis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
A young man presents to the outpatient department with urethral discharge. Urinalysis shows neutrophils but there are no bacteria found. What is the most likely cause?

A patient complains of dysuria, fever, urinary frequency, and hematuria. His urinalysis shows numerous white blood cells, nitrite positive, and few red blood cells. What is true about the most common causative agent?
Which of the following is an extrinsic cause of unilateral partial obstruction of the ureter?
Which of the following urine culture results gives the diagnosis of urinary tract infection?
A two-year-old boy presented with recurrent urinary tract infections. What is the most likely cause?
A female patient was on antibiotic therapy for urinary tract infections. She later developed a fever and rash. Her urine had increased eosinophils. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old man came with a complaint of recurrent flank pain. Ultrasound revealed hydronephrosis with distension of the pelvis and calyces but the bladder and ureters were normal. What is the most likely cause of his complaint?

A 65-year-old male came with complaints of fever, hematuria, and flank pain. He had white blood cell casts in his urine and his culture showed 10⁴ CFU/ml. What direction of investigation should be followed?

answers.option: Treat as a case of urinary tract infection
Urine culture should be done again

question: Bilateral agenesis of the kidneys is associated with which of the following?
A 4-year-old boy showed signs of diffuse effacement of foot processes on electron microscopy. What is correct about the disease?

Anti-glomerular basement membrane antibody-induced glomerulonephritis accounts for less than 5% cases of human glomerulonephritis. Which of the following is the most appropriate example of this nephropathy?
Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding renal transplantation?

answers.option: HLA compatibility is sometimes not required
Allergen test is performed on potential recipient
ABO compatibility between donor and recipient is essential
HLA compatibility for minor antigens is not required
Immunosuppressant drugs are prescribed to selected transplant patients

question: Which of the following organisms is the most common cause of community-acquired urinary tract infections?
Which of the following is least frequently associated with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis?
Which of the following is least likely to be seen in nephrotic syndrome?
Which of the following is least likely to be correct about xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis?

answers.option: Accumulation of foamy macrophages with plasma cells, lymphocytes and giant cells

question: A 5-year-old boy presents to the outpatient clinic with generalized and periorbital edema. Blood tests and urine analysis reveal hypoalbuminemia, lipiduria, and 3.7 g proteinuria. A renal biopsy is performed. Which of the following electron microscopic features is most likely to be present in this case?

answers.option: Effacement of foot process but no deposits
Thick glomerular basement membrane with immune complex deposition

question: Which of the following is the most common route of spread of acute pyelonephritis?

answers.option: Ascending spread from urethra and bladder

question: Which of the following factors help distinguish that hematuria is of renal origin and not from the bladder?

A 55-year-old man presents with hypertension, puffiness of his face, and darkening of urine. Serum levels of blood urea nitrogen (BUN) are raised. Urinalysis reports numerous RBCs and occasional red cell casts. He was admitted for further investigations. Which of the following serum proteins will be found depleted in this patient suggesting an immune-complex mediated renal involvement?

A 10-year-old boy abruptly develops malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and hematuria (smoky or cola-colored urine) one to two weeks after recovery from a sore throat. The patient has red cell casts in the urine, mild proteinuria (< 1 gm/day), periorbital edema, and mild to moderate hypertension. Which of the following best describes this patient's medical condition?

A 7-year-old boy has been diagnosed with post-infectious glomerulonephritis resulting in nephritic syndrome. The child has hematuria as a part of this syndrome. Which of the following findings on urinalysis would suggest that RBCs in his urine are coming from the kidneys and not from lower down the urinary tract?
Muscle-invasive bladder cancers are associated with which of the following?

answers.option: Activations of TP53 & RB tumor suppressor genes
Inactivation of TP53 & Rb tumor suppressor genes

question: A 42-year-old man has had recurrent episodes of urinary tract infections (UTIs) over the last six months. Urine culture has yielded the growth of Proteus mirabilis on three occasions. Which one of the following could be the most likely underlying cause?

A patient with severe recurrent gout, who had been taking high doses of analgesics, presented with malaise and nausea. Laboratory findings showed raised serum urea and creatinine levels. Which one of the following diseases is he suffering from?

A 45-year-old man had left flank pain. Ultrasonography showed bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple variable-size cysts in both the cortex and medulla. A few cysts in the liver were also seen. What is the most likely pattern of inheritance of this disease?

A 54-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with a history of recurrent headaches due to sinusitis, for which he took non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) regularly. His initial investigations showed a Hb of 11.2 gm/dl, a total leukocyte count (TLC) of 4.8 ×10 ³, 58% neutrophils, 28% lymphocytes, 12% eosinophils, and 2% monocytes. Urea is 98 mg/dl and creatinine is 2.1 gm/dl. Urine analysis is positive for protein. What is the most likely reason for his deranged laboratory tests?
What is seen on electron microscopy (EM) in minimal change disease?

answers.option: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane

question: Which of the following is true regarding minimal change disease?
What is the induction factor for the metanephrogenic blastema and ureteric bud?
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is most likely to progress to which of the following?
How can the reabsorption in peritubular capillaries be increased?

answers.option: Decrease colloid osmotic pressure in the renal interstitium

question: Which of the following collagen types is present in the glomerular basement membrane?

A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with intense pain in her lower back and a burning sensation upon urination. She was managed as a case of urinary tract infection. Which antibiotic is most commonly used to treat a UTI?
Which of the following is the key mediator of inflammation in crescentic glomerulonephritis?

A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with intense pain in the lower back and a burning sensation upon urination. Urine analysis shows Gram-negative rods. Which of the following is most likely the cause of her urinary tract infection (UTI)?
In membranous nephropathy, which of the following is the primary site of immune deposition?
In minimal change disease, which of the following is the characteristic finding?

answers.option: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane
Loss of foot processes in podocytes

question: Which of the following is an example of glomerulonephritis resulting from the deposition of circulating immune complexes?
Which of the following types of T cells is primarily involved in cell-mediated glomerulonephritis?
Which of the following is a common cause of cell-mediated glomerulonephritis?
A 50-year-old male with prostate cancer presents with fever and dysuria. Urine culture is positive for Enterococcus faecalis. What is the likely underlying cause of pyelonephritis in this patient?

A 10-year-old boy presents with facial edema and hypertension (BP 180/110 mmHg) following a streptococcal throat infection. Physical examination reveals oliguria, and a 24-hour urine collection demonstrates hematuria. Which of the following findings in his urinalysis would suggest that the hematuria is caused by kidney involvement and not by bleeding from the urinary bladder?

A 44-year-old man presents with scanty, reddish-brown urine. Urinalysis reveals 4+ proteinuria, numerous RBCs, and occasional RBC casts. A renal biopsy (PAS stain) shows crescent-shaped proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells. Which of the following is the most probable disease?

A 10-year-old girl presents with fever (100°F), hypertension (BP 180/110 mmHg), hematuria with red blood cell casts, and oliguria. A 24-hour urine collection shows less than 1 gram of protein loss. Which of the following is the most likely condition she is suffering from?

A 54-year-old female presents with five days of left flank pain, hematuria, chills, nausea, and vomiting. A non-tender mass is palpable in the right lumbar and hypochondriac region. A CT scan with contrast confirms a staghorn calculus with dilatation of the calyces, cortical thinning, perinephric abscess, perinephric stranding, and collection along the anterior lower pole of the left kidney, consistent with Xanthogranulomatous Pyelonephritis. Which of the following conditions resembles Xanthogranulomatous Pyelonephritis?

A 38-year-old female presents with fever with rigors, right loin pain, dysuria, and changes in urine color with a foul odor for five days. She had visited a private clinic three weeks earlier for a persistent fever and received parenteral antibiotics. On physical examination, she is febrile (temperature 38.5°C), heart rate 93 bpm, and blood pressure 117/65 mmHg. Radiological imaging shows an asymmetrically contracted kidney with blunting and deformity of the calyces. What is the most likely diagnosis?
